question: Question_06_(a)
sols:
\_\_NOTOC\_\_ If $\displaystyle x' = 0$ then either $x=0$ or $x=3-y$.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Using $\displaystyle x = 0$ in $y' = 0$ we get $y=0,1$. This gives two
  critical points: (0,0) and (0,1).
\item
  Using $\displaystyle x=3-y$ in $y' = 0$ we get $y=0,2$. In this case,
  \emph{x=3} when \emph{y=0}, and \emph{x=1} when \emph{y=2}. This gives
  two more critical points (1,2) and (3,0).
\end{itemize}

Considering the full system, we have

\begin{align*}\begin{pmatrix} x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3x - x^2 - xy \\ y + xy - y^2 \end{pmatrix}\end{align*}

Labelling $\displaystyle f(x,y) = 3x - x^2 - xy$ and
$\displaystyle g(x,y) = y + xy - y^2$, the Jacobian of the system at
$(x,y)$ is

\begin{align*}J = \begin{pmatrix} f_x & f_y \\ g_x & g_y \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 - 2x - y & -x \\ y & 1 + x - 2y \end{pmatrix}\end{align*}

The Jacobian evaluated at the critical points gives us information about
the local stability of the critical points.

\subsubsection{At \emph{(x,y) = (0,0)}}\label{at-xy-00}

\begin{align*}J(0,0) = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\end{align*} which has
eigenvalues of +1 and +3. Thus (0,0) is an unstable node (both
eigenvalues are real and positive).

\subsubsection{At \emph{(x,y) = (0,1)}}\label{at-xy-01}

\begin{align*}J(0,1) = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}\end{align*} which has
eigenvalues of +2 and -1 (being lower triangular, the eigenvalues are
the diagonal entries). As the eigenvalues are real and of opposite sign,
(0,1) is a saddle point.

\subsubsection{At \emph{(x,y) = (3,0)}}\label{at-xy-30}

\begin{align*}J(3,0) = \begin{pmatrix} -3 & -3 \\ 0 & 4 \end{pmatrix}\end{align*} having
eigenvalues of -3 and +4 (the matrix is upper triangular and its
eigenvalues are the diagonal entries). We thus have (3,0) is a saddle
point.

\subsubsection{At \emph{(x,y) = (1,2)}}\label{at-xy-12}

\begin{align*}J(1,2) = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & -1 \\ 2 & -2 \end{pmatrix}.\end{align*} The
eigenvalues satisfy the characteristic polynomial
$\lambda^2 + 3 \lambda + 4 = 0$ so
$\lambda^\pm = \frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{9 - 16}}{2} = -3/2 \pm \sqrt{7} i/2.$
These eigenvalues have a nonzero imaginary part giving rise to a
spiral/ellipse. As there real components are negative, we have a stable
spiral at (1,2).
hints:
At a critical point, both dx/dt and dy/dt must be 0. Be careful to
consider all possible cases.
